18. The status quo has for too long let members of Congress (of both parties) have their cake and eat it too‚Äîoften at great expense to the American people. In the immortal words of Lord Farquaad in the first Shrek movie, ‚Äúthat is a sacrifice [they‚Äôre] willing to make.‚Äù No more!

17. Members of Congress who delegate substantive lawmaking power to bureaucrats should be exposed for what they‚Äôre doing: allowing themselves to (1) claim credit for a law‚Äôs lofty aims, but (2) preserve deniability for controversial uses of the power it recklessly confers.
16. Congress needs to enact sweeping reforms to the federal regulatory rulemaking process, starting with the REINS Act.

15. Federal agency rules cost Americans an estimated $2 trillion each year. Low and middle-income earners are disproportionately impacted by those costs, which inevitably lead to higher prices on everything they buy.

14. Even if you like ATF‚Äôs pistol brace rule (or any other federal regulations), it‚Äôs hard to deny that bad things happen when lawmaking power is wielded by those who aren‚Äôt accountable to the people.

13. Giving ATF and other agencies discretion to promulgate binding laws that haven‚Äôt been enacted by Congress (and, as with the pistol brace rule, couldn‚Äôt be enacted), disrespects not only the Constitution, but the people themselves, whose interests it was designed to protect.

12. I intensely dislike ATF‚Äôs pistol brace rule. Enough of my colleagues in the Senate (and enough of our counterparts in the House) share that view that I can confidently say that the rule could NOT be enacted into law by this Congress.

11. It is, moreover, already compelled by any sound reading of the Constitution, which doesn‚Äôt allow federal law to be made or modified without both houses of Congress passing the same text, and then submitting it to the president.
10. This approach is entirely agnostic as to any substantive policy issue, and is neither Democratic (or liberal) nor Republican (or conservative).

9. Such rules should be made binding on the public only if Congress chooses to enact them into law, following the formula prescribed by Article I, Section 7. Existing law doesn‚Äôt require that, but it should. The REINS Act would largely fix this problem.

8. ATF‚Äôs pistol brace rule is a good example of a regulation that materially changes the legal obligations imposed by the federal government on the American people, and therefore should not be adopted administratively through authority delegated by Congress.

7. The REINS Act is a bill that would restore this balance by treating many agency rules not as binding laws, but as proposals that could become law only if passed by both houses of Congress and then presented to the president for signature, veto, or acquiescence.

6. Federal bureaucrats don‚Äôt stand for election, and therefore aren‚Äôt accountable to the people. In fact, they‚Äôre almost impossible to fire. Giving them power to make law is both dangerously anti-democratic and fundamentally at odds with the Constitution‚Äôs structural guarantees.

5. While the Supreme Court acknowledges constitutional limitations on Congress‚Äôs power to delegate some of its authority, it has been reluctant to enforce those limits. Congress has therefore continued to delegate its lawmaking power, to the detriment of the American people.

4. But when an administrative rule imposes new legal obligations on the public‚Äîobligations not imposed by and apparent on the face of any law enacted by Congress‚Äîthe rule shouldn‚Äôt be treated as binding law, but as a proposal that can‚Äôt take effect without Congress enacting it.
3. It‚Äôs fine for federal agencies to prescribe ‚Äúinternal‚Äù rules binding only on the government itself (e.g., rules specifying office hours, internal operating procedures, etc.).

2. When an agency makes law (using delegated power), the process is described as ‚Äúrulemaking.‚Äù Consistent with the Constitution (Art. I, Sec. 7), ‚Äúrules‚Äù imposing new legal obligations on the American people should be enacted only by Congress itself, not by unelected bureaucrats.
